Well give it a shot. I tried HyperNEAT myself and there wasn't much 
better=
 result than regular NEAT. Besides, in HyperNEAT you are 
restricted to a f=
ixed substrate topology (i.e. the networks that you 
evaluate will have the=
 same number of neurons) which may not be the 
right thing for this domain.=
 I believe there is an ongoing research 
about evolving substrates but ther=
e is still not a best method for 
doing this. 
Of course HyperNEAT can lear=
n basically everything that regular NEAT 
can, but it is the computational =
effort that must be considered. 
Building phenotypes in HyperNEAT is expens=
ive. Evaluating them is 
expensive too, if the first individuals (with even=
 the simplest 
CPPNs) generate many connections. 
HyperNEAT is designed to =
tackle problems that have geometric 
regularities, this is what it is best =
of. In other domains without 
regularities it will perform worse than regul=
ar NEAT. 

Peter

uffice.  Am I correct here?

at have nothing to do with

and thus is more likely to create
> modular
> > phenotypes that exhibit rep=
etitions and symmetry (with and without
> > variation).
> > 
> > Unless I a=
m mistaken, these benefits can cause HyperNEAT to
> outperform NEAT
> > eve=
n on problems where geometry is not being exploited. Does that 
sound

ight to everyone?
